android-cloexec-open.description:
Description

A common source of security bugs is code that opens a file without using the
O_CLOEXEC
flag. Without that flag, an opened sensitive file would remain
open across a fork+exec to a lower-privileged SELinux domain, leaking that
sensitive data. Open-like functions including
open()
,
openat()
, and
open64()
should include
O_CLOEXEC
in their flags argument.

Examples:

open
(
"filename"
,
O_RDWR
);
open64
(
"filename"
,
O_RDWR
);
openat
(
0
,
"filename"
,
O_RDWR
);
// becomes
open
(
"filename"
,
O_RDWR
|
O_CLOEXEC
);
open64
(
"filename"
,
O_RDWR
|
O_CLOEXEC
);
openat
(
0
,
"filename"
,
O_RDWR
|
O_CLOEXEC
);
android-cloexec-open.option:
Static analysis (Clang-Tidy) options are configured via .clang-tidy file.

This rule has no specific options.
